express_entry.title: Express Entry
express_entry.description: Canada's fastest pathway to permanent residence for skilled workers. Learn about CRS scoring, draw patterns, and application strategies.

guides.title: Express Entry Complete Guide
guides.subtitle: Everything you need to know about Canada's flagship immigration system
guides.overview: Express Entry is Canada's premier immigration system for skilled workers, managing applications for three federal economic immigration programs. Since 2015, it has become the fastest pathway to Canadian permanent residence, with processing times of 6 months or less.

sections.title: What is Express Entry?
sections.content: Express Entry is an online system that manages applications for permanent residence under three federal economic immigration programs: Federal Skilled Worker (FSW), Federal Skilled Trades (FST), and Canadian Experience Class (CEC). Candidates create profiles, receive Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) scores, and are ranked against each other in the Express Entry pool.

sections.title: How It Works
sections.content:
1. Check your eligibility for one or more Express Entry programs
2. Gather required documents (ECA, language tests, work experience letters)
3. Create your Express Entry profile
4. Receive your CRS score and enter the pool
5. Receive an Invitation to Apply (ITA) if your score is above the cutoff
6. Submit your complete application within 60 days
7. Receive your PR decision (typically within 6 months)

sections.title: CRS Score Factors
sections.content: Your CRS score is calculated based on: Age (max 110 points), Education (max 150 points), Language proficiency (max 160 points), Canadian work experience (max 80 points), Spouse factors (if applicable), Transferability factors, and Additional points for provincial nomination (+600), job offer (+50-200), Canadian education (+15-30), or French proficiency (+25-50).

guides.title: CRS Scoring Deep Dive
guides.subtitle: Understand exactly how your CRS score is calculated
guides.overview: The Comprehensive Ranking System (CRS) is the points-based system used to rank Express Entry candidates. Understanding how each factor contributes to your score is essential for maximizing your chances of receiving an ITA.

guides.title: How to Improve Your CRS Score
guides.subtitle: Proven strategies to boost your score and get an ITA faster
guides.overview: If your CRS score is below recent draw cutoffs, there are several proven strategies to improve your ranking. From retaking language tests to gaining Canadian experience, learn the most effective ways to increase your score.

guides.title: Category-Based Draws Explained
guides.subtitle: Healthcare, STEM, French, and Trade occupation draws
guides.overview: Since 2023, IRCC has been conducting category-based draws targeting specific occupations and skills. These draws often have significantly lower CRS cutoffs than general draws, making them an excellent opportunity for eligible candidates.

provincial_programs.title: Provincial Nominee Programs
provincial_programs.description: Explore immigration streams from all 13 Canadian provinces and territories. A provincial nomination adds 600 CRS points to your Express Entry score.

provinces.name: Ontario
provinces.description: Canada's largest province with a diverse economy and the most Express Entry-aligned PNP streams.

streams.name: Human Capital Priorities
streams.description: For candidates with Express Entry profiles in in-demand occupations

streams.name: Skilled Trades
streams.description: For skilled tradespeople with Ontario job offers or work experience

streams.name: French-Speaking Skilled Worker
streams.description: For French-speaking candidates with strong English proficiency

streams.name: Tech Draw
streams.description: Periodic draws targeting tech occupations

streams.name: Employer Job Offer
streams.description: For candidates with valid job offers from Ontario employers

streams.name: Masters Graduate
streams.description: For graduates of Ontario master's programs

streams.name: PhD Graduate
streams.description: For graduates of Ontario PhD programs

provinces.name: British Columbia
provinces.description: Home to Canada's tech hub in Vancouver with dedicated streams for tech workers.

streams.name: BC PNP Tech
streams.description: Priority processing for 29 in-demand tech occupations

streams.name: Skilled Worker
streams.description: For skilled workers with BC job offers

streams.name: Healthcare Professional
streams.description: For doctors, nurses, and allied health professionals

streams.name: International Graduate
streams.description: For recent graduates from Canadian post-secondary institutions

streams.name: Entry Level and Semi-Skilled
streams.description: For workers in tourism, hospitality, and food processing in specific regions

provinces.name: Alberta
provinces.description: Strong economy driven by energy, agriculture, and a growing tech sector.

streams.name: Alberta Express Entry
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with ties to Alberta

streams.name: Alberta Opportunity Stream
streams.description: For foreign workers already employed in Alberta

streams.name: Rural Renewal Stream
streams.description: For workers in rural Alberta communities

streams.name: Tourism and Hospitality Stream
streams.description: For workers in Alberta's tourism sector

provinces.name: Saskatchewan
provinces.description: Agriculture and resource-based economy with strong demand for skilled workers.

streams.name: International Skilled Worker
streams.description: For skilled workers with occupation on in-demand list

streams.name: Saskatchewan Experience
streams.description: For foreign workers with Saskatchewan work experience

streams.name: Entrepreneur
streams.description: For entrepreneurs wanting to start or buy a business in SK

provinces.name: Manitoba
provinces.description: Diverse economy with strong settlement support and community connections.

streams.name: Skilled Worker in Manitoba
streams.description: For workers with ongoing employment in Manitoba

streams.name: Skilled Worker Overseas
streams.description: For overseas workers with strong Manitoba connections

streams.name: International Education Stream
streams.description: For graduates of Manitoba post-secondary institutions

provinces.name: Nova Scotia
provinces.description: Atlantic province with growing tech and healthcare sectors.

streams.name: Labour Market Priorities
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with in-demand skills

streams.name: Skilled Worker
streams.description: For workers with Nova Scotia job offers

streams.name: Physician Stream
streams.description: For doctors with job offers from NS health authorities

provinces.name: New Brunswick
provinces.description: Bilingual Atlantic province with growing immigration targets.

streams.name: Express Entry Labour Market
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with NB job offers or work experience

streams.name: Skilled Worker with Employer Support
streams.description: For workers with NB job offers

streams.name: Post-Graduate Entrepreneurial
streams.description: For NB graduates wanting to start businesses

provinces.name: Prince Edward Island
provinces.description: Canada's smallest province with welcoming communities.

streams.name: Labour Impact
streams.description: For skilled workers and critical workers with PEI job offers

streams.name: Express Entry
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with PEI job offers

provinces.name: Newfoundland and Labrador
provinces.description: Atlantic province with resource-based economy and growing tech sector.

streams.name: Express Entry Skilled Worker
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with NL job offers

streams.name: Skilled Worker
streams.description: For skilled workers with NL job offers

streams.name: International Graduate

provinces.description: Northern territory with unique lifestyle and strong demand for workers.

streams.description: For skilled workers with Yukon job offers

streams.name: Express Entry

streams.name: Employer Driven

streams.name: Express Entry
streams.description: For Express Entry candidates with NWT job offers

provinces.name: Nunavut
provinces.description: Canada's newest and largest territory. Currently does not have an active PNP.

study_permit.title: Study in Canada
study_permit.description: Complete guides to studying in Canada, from application to post-graduation work permits and pathways to permanent residence.

guides.title: Study Permit Application Guide
guides.subtitle: Step-by-step guide to applying for your Canadian study permit
guides.overview: A study permit allows you to study at a designated learning institution (DLI) in Canada. This comprehensive guide covers eligibility, required documents, application process, and tips for approval.

guides.title: Choosing the Right DLI
guides.subtitle: How to select a Designated Learning Institution
guides.overview: Not all Canadian schools qualify you for a study permit or post-graduation work permit. Learn how to verify DLI status and choose programs that support your immigration goals.

guides.title: Post-Graduation Work Permit (PGWP)
guides.subtitle: Work in Canada after your studies
guides.overview: The PGWP allows you to work in Canada for up to 3 years after graduation. Learn about eligibility requirements, application timing, and how it leads to permanent residence.

guides.title: Student to PR Pathway
guides.subtitle: Your complete roadmap from student to permanent resident
guides.overview: The student pathway is one of the most popular routes to Canadian PR. Learn how to maximize your chances by choosing the right program, province, and gaining Canadian experience.

guides.title: Student Direct Stream (SDS)
guides.subtitle: Faster study permit processing for eligible countries
guides.overview: The Student Direct Stream offers faster processing (typically 20 days) for applicants from eligible countries who meet specific requirements. Learn if you qualify and how to apply.

work_permit.title: Work Permits
work_permit.description: Understand the different types of Canadian work permits, from LMIA-based permits to open work permits and LMIA-exempt categories.

guides.title: Work Permit Overview
guides.subtitle: Understanding Canadian work permit categories
guides.overview: Canadian work permits come in many forms: LMIA-based, LMIA-exempt, open, and employer-specific. This guide helps you understand which type applies to your situation.

guides.title: LMIA Work Permits
guides.subtitle: Employer-sponsored work permits with Labour Market Impact Assessment
guides.overview: An LMIA is a document that a Canadian employer may need to obtain before hiring a foreign worker. Learn about the LMIA process, exemptions, and how it affects your work permit.

guides.title: Open Work Permits
guides.subtitle: Work for any employer in Canada
guides.overview: Open work permits allow you to work for any Canadian employer without needing a specific job offer. Learn about eligibility categories including spouse permits, bridging permits, and PGWP.

guides.title: International Experience Canada (IEC)
guides.subtitle: Working Holiday, Young Professionals, and Co-op programs
guides.overview: IEC allows young people from partner countries to work and travel in Canada. Learn about the three categories, eligibility requirements, and how to apply.

guides.title: Intra-Company Transfers (ICT)
guides.subtitle: For multinational company employees
guides.overview: ICT work permits allow employees of multinational companies to transfer to Canadian branches. Learn about the eligibility requirements and application process.

credentials.title: Credential Evaluation
credentials.description: Educational Credential Assessment (ECA) guides for Express Entry and professional licensing in Canada.

guides.title: WES ECA Guide
guides.subtitle: Step-by-step World Education Services credential evaluation
guides.overview: WES is the most popular credential evaluation service for Express Entry. This guide covers the application process, document requirements, and expected timelines.

guides.title: ECA Overview
guides.subtitle: Understanding Educational Credential Assessments
guides.overview: An ECA compares your foreign education to Canadian standards. Learn which organizations are designated by IRCC and how to choose the right one for your situation.

guides.title: Professional Licensing in Canada
guides.subtitle: Getting your credentials recognized for regulated professions
guides.overview: Many professions in Canada are regulated, requiring additional licensing beyond an ECA. Learn about the process for engineers, nurses, doctors, accountants, and other regulated professions.

forms.title: Immigration Forms
forms.description: Step-by-step guides for filling out IRCC immigration forms correctly. Avoid common mistakes that lead to application refusals.

guides.title: IMM 0008 Generic Application Form
guides.subtitle: The main application form for permanent residence
guides.overview: IMM 0008 is the generic application form for Canadian permanent residence. This guide covers every section with examples and tips to avoid common mistakes.

guides.title: IMM 5669 Schedule A
guides.subtitle: Background and personal history declaration
guides.overview: Schedule A (IMM 5669) is a detailed form about your background, education, employment, and travel history. Learn how to complete it accurately.

guides.title: IMM 5406 Additional Family Information
guides.subtitle: Family information form for immigration applications
guides.overview: IMM 5406 collects information about your family members. Learn who needs to be included and how to complete each section.

guides.title: IMM 1294 Application for Study Permit
guides.subtitle: Study permit application form guide
guides.overview: Complete guide to filling out the study permit application form, including tips for a successful application.

guides.title: IMM 1295 Application for Work Permit
guides.subtitle: Work permit application form guide
guides.overview: Step-by-step guide to the work permit application form for both LMIA-based and LMIA-exempt work permits.

language_tests.title: Language Tests
language_tests.description: Comprehensive guides for IELTS, CELPIP, TEF, and TCF language tests required for Canadian immigration.

guides.title: IELTS General Training Guide
guides.subtitle: Prepare for the IELTS test for Canadian immigration
guides.overview: IELTS General Training is one of the most popular English tests for Canadian immigration. Learn about the test format, scoring, and how it converts to CLB levels.

guides.title: CELPIP General Guide
guides.subtitle: Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program
guides.overview: CELPIP is a Canadian English test taken entirely on computer. Learn about the test format, advantages, and preparation strategies.

guides.title: PTE Core Guide
guides.subtitle: Pearson Test of English for Canadian immigration
guides.overview: PTE Core is the newest IRCC-approved English test. Learn about its unique computer-based format and rapid results delivery.

guides.title: French Language Tests (TEF/TCF)
guides.subtitle: French proficiency tests for Canadian immigration
guides.overview: French proficiency can significantly boost your CRS score. Learn about TEF Canada and TCF Canada tests, scoring, and the benefits of French proficiency.

guides.title: CLB Score Conversion Guide
guides.subtitle: Convert your test scores to Canadian Language Benchmark levels
guides.overview: Canadian immigration uses CLB (Canadian Language Benchmarks) levels. Learn how to convert your IELTS, CELPIP, PTE, or French test scores to CLB/NCLC levels.

family.title: Family Sponsorship
family.description: Guides for sponsoring family members to Canada, including spouses, parents, grandparents, and dependent children.

guides.title: Spousal Sponsorship Guide
guides.subtitle: Sponsor your spouse or common-law partner for PR
guides.overview: Spousal sponsorship allows Canadian citizens and permanent residents to sponsor their spouse, common-law partner, or conjugal partner for permanent residence. Learn about inland vs outland applications.

guides.title: Parents and Grandparents Program (PGP)
guides.subtitle: Sponsor your parents or grandparents for PR
guides.overview: The PGP allows Canadian citizens and permanent residents to sponsor their parents and grandparents. Learn about the lottery system, income requirements, and Super Visa alternatives.

guides.title: Super Visa for Parents/Grandparents
guides.subtitle: Long-term visitor visa for parents and grandparents
guides.overview: The Super Visa allows parents and grandparents to visit Canada for up to 5 years at a time. Learn about requirements and how it differs from regular visitor visas.

guides.title: Sponsoring Dependent Children
guides.subtitle: Including children in your immigration application
guides.overview: Learn how to include dependent children in your immigration application, age limits, and requirements for adopted children.

refugees.title: Refugees & Protected Persons
refugees.description: Information about Canada's refugee protection system and pathways for protected persons.

guides.title: Making a Refugee Claim
guides.subtitle: Understanding Canada's refugee protection process
guides.overview: Canada provides protection to people who fear persecution in their home country. Learn about the refugee claim process, eligibility, and what to expect.

guides.title: Protected Person to PR
guides.subtitle: Pathway to permanent residence for protected persons
guides.overview: Once you're recognized as a protected person in Canada, you can apply for permanent residence. Learn about the application process and requirements.
